general: This act was passed in 2003 and its main purpose is to establish an independent commission to monitor the situation in Northern Ireland, which is part of the United Kingdom. The commission will have powers to investigate certain issues and make recommendations to improve the political situation in the region. Additionally, the act makes provisions for reducing the salaries of members of the Northern Ireland Assembly and limits the amount of financial assistance given to political parties in the region. It also allows for "censure resolutions" to be passed by the assembly, which can express disapproval of the government's actions. Overall, the goal of the act is to promote stability and good governance in Northern Ireland.

series.short: "Monitoring Commission for Paramilitary Groups: Ensuring Security and Respecting National Interests"
series.text:
* The Monitoring Commission is an independent organization established to monitor activities of paramilitary groups, security normalization, and report on claims related to the pledge of office set out in Schedule 4 of the Northern Ireland Act 1998.
* The Secretary of State can confer legal capacities, privileges, and immunities on the Monitoring Commission and its members through orders.
* The Monitoring Commission must avoid prejudicing national security interests of the UK and Ireland, putting anyone's safety or life at risk, or having a prejudicial effect on any legal proceedings.
* The Secretary of State must lay copies of the Monitoring Commission's reports before each House of Parliament.

series.short: "New Law on Government Exclusions in Northern Ireland: Strengthening Peaceful Means"
series.text:
* The text describes changes to the law regarding the exclusion of individuals from holding certain positions in the government of Northern Ireland due to their involvement in violent activities or lack of commitment to peaceful means.
* The changes allow for longer periods of exclusion and give the Secretary of State additional powers to exclude individuals based on reports from the Monitoring Commission established by the Belfast Agreement.
* The text also includes new requirements for the Assembly to consider motions for resolutions related to these exclusions, and allows for temporary exclusions under exceptional circumstances.
* Simplified point 1: The text focuses on regulating the exclusion of individuals from government positions in Northern Ireland due to their involvement in violent activities or lack of commitment to peaceful means.
* Simplified point 2: The changes aim to strengthen the ability of the Secretary of State to exclude individuals from government positions based on reports from the Monitoring Commission and to ensure that the Assembly considers motions related to these exclusions.

series.short: "Northern Ireland Political Salary Reduction Act: A Measure to Promote Non-Violent Conflict Resolution"
series.text:
* The act allows for reductions in salaries of ministers and MLAs if they fail to commit to non-violent and exclusive peaceful and democratic means.
* If a political party fails to meet these requirements, their members' salaries can also be reduced.
* The Secretary of State has the power to reduce salaries if the Assembly fails to pass a resolution to do so.
* The period during which salary reductions can be made can be extended by the Assembly or the Secretary of State.
* The act also affects pension provisions for members of the Assembly.

series.short: "Financial Assistance Reduction in Northern Ireland Political Parties Act"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The act allows for reductions in financial assistance provided to political parties in Northern Ireland if they do not commit to non-violent and exclusive peaceful means.
* Simplified point 2: The act empowers the Secretary of State to direct that financial assistance should not be paid to a political party if it fails to pass a resolution supporting non-violence and exclusive peaceful means, or if it fails to extend the period by which such resolutions must be passed.
* Simplified point 3: The act sets out the process by which the Assembly can resolve to reduce or cease financial assistance to political parties, including the requirement for cross-community support and the role of the Secretary of State in exercising powers to direct reductions or non-payment.

series.short: "Northern Ireland Assembly Censure Resolutions: Promoting Non-Violent Democracy"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section of the legislation allows for censure resolutions against ministers or political parties in the Northern Ireland Assembly if they are not committed to non-violence and exclusive peaceful and democratic means.
* Simplified point 2: The section requires a minimum number of supporters for a motion to be moved, and also gives the Secretary of State the power to require the Assembly to consider such a resolution if they have not already done so.
* Simplified point 3: The section specifies that a resolution cannot be passed without cross-community support, meaning that both unionist and nationalist parties must agree on the resolution for it to be successful.

series.short: "UK Legislation - Monitoring Commission etc. Act 2003: Directions and Effects"
series.text:
* The text delimited by the triple backticks is an extract of clauses from a piece of UK Legislation with the title: Northern Ireland (Monitoring Commission etc.) Act 2003.
* General Secretary of State's directions: procedure etc.
* Directions under sections 30A, 47B, and 51B must be in writing, and a copy will be laid before parliament after the direction is given.
* If a draft of the document containing the direction is not approved by both houses of parliament within 40 days, the direction will cease to have effect.
* If the document containing the direction is rejected by either house of parliament during the 40-day period, the direction will also cease to have effect.
* The documentary evidence act of 1868 will apply to a direction given by the secretary of state as if it were not an instrument.
* Section 95A(10) of the original act adds a schedule 12A detailing the effects of applying section 95A(6) or (7).
* Paragraphs 2 through 4 of Schedule 12A apply when a direction under section 30A(5) ceases to take effect under section 95A(6) or (7).
* Sub-paragraphs (2) through (4) of Schedule 12A apply when the relevant offices are vacant immediately before the relevant time due to the direction.
* If the vacancies in the relevant offices are filled under sub-paragraph (3), section 16(8) will not apply because of the operation of sub-paragraph (2).
* Sub-paragraphs (2) through (4) of Schedule 12A apply when the relevant offices are vacant immediately before the relevant time due to the direction.
* If the vacancies in the relevant offices are not filled under sub-paragraph (3), the proceedings for an election under section 16 for the purpose of filling them will start over with the six-week period mentioned in section 16(8) being taken for the purposes of this act.
* Directions under section 47B or 51B: After the direction has stopped having effect, any determinations of the sums payable under section 47 or under the financial assistance for political parties act (Northern Ireland) 2000 will be made as if the direction had never existed. Payments will be made of any amounts that would have been paid if the direction had not been issued.
* General: The Secretary of State will report on the implementation of the agreement mentioned in section 1(1) and any changes made to the Northern Ireland Act [1998 (c.47)] by this bill.
* Short title, commencement, and repeals: This act can be referred to as the Northern Ireland (Monitoring Commission Etc.) Act 2003. It goes into effect right away, except for certain parts that will go into effect later. Sections 1 to 3 and 11 of this act, as well as sections 30A, 47B, and 51B of the Northern Ireland Act [1998 (c.47)], will expire at the end of the day the Secretary of State designates by statutory instrument.

summary: The Northern Ireland (Monitoring Commission etc.) Act 2003 is a law that establishes an independent commission to monitor the activities of paramilitary groups in Northern Ireland. The commission helps ensure security and respects national interests. The law also makes changes to the exclusion of individuals from government positions in Northern Ireland and reduces salaries of ministers and MLAs who fail to commit to non-violent and exclusive peaceful and democratic means. Additionally, the act reduces financial assistance to political parties in Northern Ireland if they do not support non-violence and exclusive peaceful means. The law also allows for censure resolutions against ministers or political parties in the Northern Ireland Assembly if they are not committed to non-violence and exclusive peaceful and democratic means. Finally, the act provides for the Secretary of State to report on the implementation of the agreement mentioned in section 1(1) and any changes made to the Northern Ireland Act [1998 (c.47)] by this bill.
